questions.question: The inner ear, or the labyrinth has a central chamber called the vestibule with a spherical and elliptical recess, each accommodating important structures of the membranous labyrinth. What structure does the elliptical recess accommodate?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Utricle Explanation: The utricle is accommodated in the elliptical recess that is situated in the medial wall of the central chamber. The vestibular system is divided into Peripheral: made of membranous labyrinth (SCC, utricle, and saccule) and vestibular nerve Membranous labyrinth: It is present in the labyrinth/inner ear enclosed by the bony labyrinth. The lateral wall of the vestibule (central chamber) of the bony labyrinth has the oval window (Option C) The medial wall has two recesses , A spherical recess that carries the saccule (Option A) An elliptical recess that carries the utricle The opening of the aqueduct of the vestibule is located below the elliptical recess which has the endolymphatic duct. The posterosuperior part of the vestibule has 5 openings of semicircular canals (Option B) . Vestibular nerve: Central processes of the vestibular or Scarpa’s ganglion forms the vestibular nerve. Transmits the signals from hair cells in the inner ear to the vestibular nuclei Central: made of the nuclei (superior, medial, lateral, descending nuclei) and fiber tracts in CNS.

questions.question: A 35-year-old patient presents with complaints of vertigo and dizziness when turning their head side to side. Upon examination, the nystagmus is horizontal. Which of the following is the most likely stimulated structure?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Lateral Semicircular Canal Explanation: The lateral/ horizontal semicircular canal responds to angular acceleration , especially in rotations along the vertical axis. When stimulated, it produces horizontal nystagmus . In the scenario described, the patient reports dizziness during head movement, and horizontal nystagmus suggests stimulation of this canal. Endolymph flow towards the cupula (ampullopetal flow) in the horizontal canal is more effective in generating this response. Orientation of SCC and Acceleration: Parameter Description Horizontal/Lateral Semicircular Canal (Option B) Detects rotations around the vertical axis; produces horizontal nystagmus. Superior/Anterior Semicircular Canal (Option A) Detects anterior-posterior head movements; produces rotatory nystagmus. Posterior Semicircular Canal (Option C) Detects vertical head movements; produces vertical nystagmus. Utricle and Saccule (Option D) Responds to linear acceleration and deceleration or gravitational pull during head tilts. Hair cells within each semicircular canal are aligned with their kinocilia in the same direction. During rotational acceleration, when the cupula moves in the direction of the kinocilia, the hair cells become depolarized, increasing neuronal activity. Conversely, movement in the opposite direction causes hyperpolarization and decreased neuronal firing. Linear acceleration: The otolith organs, comprising the utricle and sacculus , detect head movements and linear accelerations. These organs contain a sensory organ called the macula , which includes hair cells and supporting cells. These hair cells are covered by a gelatinous layer topped by the otolithic membrane , embedded with calcium carbonate crystals called otoconia . The weight of these crystals makes the otolithic membrane heavier than the surrounding structures, causing it to shift due to gravity when the head tilts. This shift creates a shearing effect between the otolithic membrane and the macula, moving the hair bundles and generating a receptor potential in the hair cells

questions.question: A 40-year-old male presents with vertigo, nausea, and vomiting. His vertigo worsens with sudden head movements, and he shows signs of horizontal nystagmus. Which of the following best describes the central vestibular connections responsible for his symptoms?

options.A: Vestibular nuclei efferents to the cerebellum provide motion awareness.
options.B: The vestibulo-ocular reflex involves CN III, IV, and VI via the MLF.
options.C: Vestibulospinal fibers connect directly to the cerebellum for balance.
options.D: The autonomic system plays no role in vestibular disorders.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) The vestibulo-ocular reflex involves CN III, IV, and VI via the MLF. coordinating eye movements with input from the vestibular system. The vestibular nuclei send efferent fibers to the motor nuclei of cranial nerves III, IV, and VI through the medial longitudinal bundle, facilitating this reflex and explaining the nystagmus. Vestibular Pathway Features: Component Function Vestibular Nerve Formed by central processes of bipolar cells in Scarpa’s ganglion, it transmits signals from the labyrinth to the brain. Vestibular Nuclei Four in number (superior, medial, lateral, descending) located in the brainstem; integrate inputs from vestibular receptors, cerebellum, reticular formation, and spinal cord. Vestibulo-ocular Reflex (VOR) Mediated by vestibular nuclei sending efferent fibers to cranial nerves III, IV, and VI through the medial longitudinal bundle, stabilizes gaze during head movement. Vestibulospinal Pathway Efferent fibers from vestibular nuclei to the motor part of the spinal cord coordinate head, neck, and body movements. Cerebellar Connections Receives inputs from vestibular nuclei (vestibulocerebellar fibers) to coordinate balance and maintain body equilibrium. Autonomic Nervous System Explains nausea, vomiting, sweating, and pallor seen in vestibular disorders like Ménière’s disease. questions.question: A 30-year-old patient presents with involuntary oscillatory eye movements, vertigo and hearing loss in the right ear. The nystagmus is horizontal, with a fast phase to the right, more pronounced in darkness and improves when focusing on a fixed point. There is no associated nausea or vomiting. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: Central vestibular nystagmus due to a cerebellar lesion
options.B: Peripheral vestibular nystagmus due to serous labyrinthitis
options.C: Peripheral vestibular nystagmus due to purulent labyrinthitis
options.D: Central vestibular nystagmus due to Arnold-Chiari malformation

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Peripheral vestibular nystagmus due to serous labyrinthitis Explanation: The patient’s horizontal nystagmus , with a fast phase to the right, worsens in darkness and improves with fixation , which suggests peripheral vestibular nystagmus due to serous labyrinthitis. Feature Peripheral Nystagmus Central Nystagmus Location of lesion Labyrinth or vestibulocochlear (VIII) nerve Central neural pathways (vestibular nuclei, brainstem, cerebellum) Latency 2-20 seconds No latency Duration Less than 1 minute More than 1 minute Type of Nystagmus Spontaneous nystagmus Gaze-Evoked Nystagmus Direction of Nystagmus Fixed, towards the undermost ear Change with direction of gaze Fatigability Fatigable Non-fatigable Response to Visual Fixation Suppressed by Optic fixation; Worsens in darkness or with Frenzel glasses (+20 dioptre glasses), both abolishing optic fixation Cannot be suppressed Accompanying Symptoms Severe vertigo Loss of hearing in one ear Ringing in one or both ears Difficulty focusing vision Loss of balance None or slight: Impairment in speech Weakness or numbness Gait disturbance Impairment in vision In Purulent Labyrinthitis (Option C) , Vertigo is due to the inner ear bacterial infection, with total loss of cochlear and vestibular functions. Nystagmus would be on the opposite side, and there would be severe nausea and vomiting. Central Vestibular Nystagmus (Option A and D) does not improve with optic fixation and has changing directions. Reference: Dhingra Diseases Of Ear, Nose And Throat & Head And Neck Surgery, Edition 8, Pg 47, 53. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430797/# https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441861/

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the Fitzgerald-Hallpike manoeuvre is false? cross-contamination of effects. preponderance is observed.

options.A: The temperature of the water used for stimulation is 44°C for hot water and 30°C for cold water.
options.B: A gap of 8-10 minutes is maintained between the cold and hot water stimulations to avoid
options.C: A normal response to cold water stimulation is horizontal nystagmus towards the ipsilateral side.
options.D: The test helps to assess vestibular function and can indicate central pathology if directional

questions.explanation: the ipsilateral side. Correct Answer: C) A normal response to cold water stimulation is horizontal nystagmus towards the ipsilateral side. Explanation: The correct temperatures for the hot and cold water stimulation in the Fitzgerald-Hallpike manoeuvre are 44°C and 30°C. These specific temperatures are essential to provoke the expected responses from the labyrinth and assess the vestibular function effectively. ( Statement A) A gap of 8-10 minutes between the cold and hot water stimulations is provided. This interval is important to allow the vestibular system to return to a baseline state, ensuring the stimuli are distinct and do not overlap, thus maintaining the accuracy of the test results. ( Statement B) The correct response to cold water stimulation is horizontal nystagmus towards the contralateral side, not the ipsilateral side. On the other hand, hot water causes nystagmus towards the ipsilateral side. ( Statement C) The Fitzgerald-Hallpike manoeuvre is a crucial test for evaluating vestibular function. If a directional preponderance (dominance of nystagmus in one direction) is observed, it suggests the possibility of central pathology, such as brainstem or cerebellar disorders, which may need further investigation. ( Statement D) Caloric tests and their interpretations: Purpose Induces nystagmus by thermal stimulation of the vestibular system; tests each labyrinth separately. Assesses if vertigo induced by the test is similar to the patient's episodes, indicating labyrinthine origin. Modified Kobrak Test Procedure : Patient seated with head tilted 60° back. Ear irrigated with ice water (5, 10, 20, 40 mL) for 60 s. Normal Response : Nystagmus towards the opposite ear with 5 mL. Hypoactive Labyrinth : Response with increased volumes of water. Dead Labyrinth : No response to 40 mL Fitzgerald-Hallpike Test (Bithermal Caloric Test) Procedure : Patient supine with head tilted 30° forward. Ears irrigated alternately with water at 30°C and 44°C for 40 s each. Observation : Record time taken from start of irrigation to end of nystagmus ; chart on a calorigram. Re-test : With water at 20°C if no nystagmus is seen. Observation: Cold water causes nystagmus to the opposite side and warm water to the same side. Assessment : Canal Paresis : Weaker response from one side compared to the other. Directional Preponderance : Nystagmus is more on one side than the other, 25%-30% or more difference. Occurs towards the side of a central lesion and away from the side of a peripheral lesion. Cold-Air Caloric Test Procedure : Cold air is blown into the ear via a Dundas Grant tube cooled by ethyl chloride. Use : For cases with tympanic membrane perforation. Type : Rough qualitative test.

questions.question: While assessing a patient’s vestibular function, an ENT surgeon repeatedly presses and releases the tragus of the patient, eliciting a positive response. What would this finding indicate?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Perilymph fistula Explanation: The test being performed here is the fistula test in which a positive test shows nystagmus caused due to a perilymph fistula in the labyrinth. Fistula test: Purpose To Assess the integrity of the bony labyrinth and detect perilymph fistulas (abnormal openings in the bony labyrinth) Principle Pressure changes in the external ear canal can be transmitted to the inner ear through a fistula, triggering vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR), resulting in nystagmus and possibly vertigo Procedure Pressure Application: Intermittent pressure applied on the tragus or using a Siegel's speculum. Observation: Eyes are observed for nystagmus and the patient is queried about vertigo. Interpretation Positive Fistula Test: Indicates a perilymph fistula Nystagmus direction helps locate the fistula Indicates a functional labyrinth Negative Fistula Test: Usually indicates intact bony labyrinth False negatives can occur if covered by cholesteatoma Positive test causes Erosion of horizontal semicircular canals as in cholesteatoma Surgically created window in horizontal canal Superior canal dehiscence Abnormal opening in the oval or round window Negative test No fistula False-negative causes Surgically confirmed cases of labyrinthine fistula Cholesteatoma covers the site of fistula Dead labyrinth False-Positive (Hennebert's Sign) Hennebert's Sign: Positive test without a fistula; can occur in: Congenital Syphilis: Hypermobile stapes footplate. Ménière's Disease: Due to a distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Pg: 47, 48.

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman is being evaluated in the ENT clinic for vertigo when she gets up from bed. Which of the following tests would be useful for diagnosing benign paroxysmal positional vertigo?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Dix-Hallpike test Explanation: The dix-Hallpike test is used to diagnose benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). Dix-Hallpike Test: Identifies benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). Procedure: The patient is moved from sitting with head turned at 45° to one side to lying with the head hanging off the edge of the table at 30° (to the horizontal) and rotated to target different semicircular canals. Observation: Observe nystagmus, which is typically delayed, lasts less than a minute, and has a torsional component. Use: Effective for diagnosing BPPV. Helps identify the affected semicircular canal. Baranay’s Rotational Chair test (Option B) : Assesses the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) by rotating the patient in a chair. Galvanic test (Option C) : Differentiates between lesions affecting the vestibular end organ and the vestibular nerve. Dunda’s Grant test (Option D) : Also known as cold-air caloric test is an alternative to caloric testing using water, used when water irrigation is contraindicated (e.g., perforated eardrum)

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about vestibular evoked myogenic potentials?

options.A: The cervical VEMP is picked up in the sternocleidomastoid
options.B: The vestibulospinal arc mediates through the lower brainstem
options.C: The ocular muscle that show potentials are the inferior oblique and inferior rectus
options.D: It can be used in diagnosing the origin of a neuroma

questions.explanation: rectus Correct Answer: C) The ocular muscles that show potentials are the inferior oblique and inferior rectus Explanation: The ocular muscles that show myogenic potential during a VEMP are the inferior oblique and superior rectus. Vestibular Evoked Myogenic Potentials (VEMP): It is a test to study the function of otolith organs, the saccule and utricle. Their normal function is linear acceleration. They are stimulated by the loud sound of air or bone conduction. cVEMP (Cervical VEMP) oVEMP (Ocular VEMP) Target muscle Sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle in the neck Ocular muscles (inferior oblique or superior rectus) Nerve pathway Saccule → Inferior vestibular nerve → Vestibular nuclei → Ipsilateral vestibulospinal tract → Spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) → SCM Utricle → Superior vestibular nerve → Vestibular nuclei → Medial longitudinal fasciculus → Oculomotor nerve (CN III) → Inferior oblique and superior rectus muscles Stimulation Primarily, air-conducted sounds stimulate the saccule Bone-conducted sounds, stimulating both saccule and utricle Clinical uses Assessing saccular function Investigating acoustic neuroma (inferior vestibular nerve) Diagnosing Ménière's disease Assessing utricular function Investigating acoustic neuroma (superior vestibular nerve) Diagnosing superior canal dehiscence Differences Sensitive to air-conducted sounds Vestibulospinal arc is mediated through the lower brain stem Responds to both air and bone conduction Vestibulo-ocular reflex is mediated through the upper brainstem

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with sudden-onset vertigo and difficulty maintaining gaze stability during head movements. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to assess vestibulo-ocular reflex?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Head Impulse Test Explanation: The head impulse test directly evaluates the Vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) , which is crucial for maintaining gaze stability during head movements. Supine Roll Test (Option A): Used to diagnose horizontal semicircular canal BPPV by eliciting horizontal nystagmus. Head Impulse Test/ Head Thrust Test (Option C): Evaluates the vestibulo-ocular reflex. Romberg Test (Option B): Removes visual and vestibular components that contribute to maintaining balance, helping to identify proprioception related neurologic disease. Unterberger Test/ Fukuda Stepping Test (Option D): Identifies unilateral vestibular deficit by rotations in the direction of the vestibular loss.

questions.question: A 56-year-old woman comes to the ENT department complaining of vertigo. She also has double vision, with nystagmus and difficulty in swallowing but no hearing loss . Which of the following disorders could be a cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Central vestibular disorders Explanation: The above clinical scenario points to central vestibular disorders as they present with vertigo with visual disturbances and other neurological symptoms like difficulty in swallowing but typically no hearing abnormalities. Peripheral Vestibular Disorders (Option A) Central Vestibular Disorders Origin Inner ear or vestibular nerve (cranial nerve VIII) Brainstem, cerebellum, or other central nervous system structures Examples Ménière's Disease Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV) Vestibular Neuronitis Labyrinthitis Vestibulotoxic Drugs Head Trauma Perilymph Fistula Acoustic Neuroma Syphilis Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency Posteroinferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA) Syndrome(Wallenberg syndrome) Basilar Migraine Cerebellar Disease Multiple Sclerosis Tumors of the Brainstem and Cerebellum Epilepsy Cervical vertigo Symptoms Vertigo, often with hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness Vertigo, often with additional neurological symptoms like double vision, difficulty swallowing, drop attacks, or weakness Hearing Loss Common, especially with inner ear disorders (e.g., Ménière's disease, labyrinthitis) Less common, central disorders typically do not affect hearing directly Nystagmus Characteristics Often changes direction based on gaze; typically intermittent May be direction-fixed or more persistent; often associated with other neurological signs Compensation Often improves over time as the brain adapts; recovery can be expected Less predictable; central disorders may not fully compensate, leading to chronic symptoms Ocular vertigo (Option C) is caused by a mismatch of information from the eyes, labyrinths and somatosensory systems, which normally send signals that help maintain body balance. It may occur in cases of acute extraocular muscle paresis or high errors of refraction. Psychogenic vertigo (Option D) is suspected in patients suffering from emotional stress and anxiety. Other symptoms of neurosis, like palpitations, fatigue, insomnia, sweating and tremors, may be seen, but nystagmus and hearing loss are not seen. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Page no: 52-55.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of severe vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sensation of fullness in the left ear. An Audiogram is taken and is shown below. Which of the following structures is primarily involved in the pathophysiology of the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Endolymphatic sac Explanation: Symptoms like vertigo, tinnitus, sensorineural hearing loss, and aural fullness along with audiogram findings of sensorineural hearing loss (low frequency sensorineural hearing loss, upslopping pattern) point towards diagnosis of Ménière’s disease. It is caused by the dysfunction in the endolymphatic sac , caused by overproduction or malabsorption of endolymph , leading to Endolymphatic hydrops , which is the hallmark of this disease. The resulting accumulation of endolymph distends the membranous labyrinth, affecting the cochlea and vestibular system causing the classic symptoms. Sequence of symptoms in Ménière’s disease: Tinnitus → Hearing loss → Vertigo (± vagal disturbances such as abdominal cramps, diarrhea, cold sweats, pallor and bradycardia) Structures Involved in Ménière's Disease: Structure Role in Ménière's Disease Endolymphatic sac Dysfunction causes defective absorption of endolymph, leading to endolymphatic hydrops, which results in vertigo, tinnitus, hearing loss, and aural fullness. Cochlear duct (scala media) Distension of the cochlear duct affects hearing, leading to sensorineural hearing loss . It is the primary site affected in the auditory portion of the inner ear. Saccule Distended saccule may press against the stapes footplate , potentially contributing to vestibular symptoms and vertigo in the advanced stages of the disease. (Option C) Semicircular canals Secondary involvement causes vestibular symptoms such as vertigo , but they are not the primary site of the pathology in Ménière’s disease. questions.question: A 55-year-old woman experiences brief vertigo when turning in bed. A test is performed as shown below, and horizontal nystagmus is observed. Which of the following tests was performed?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Supine roll test Explanation: The supine roll test is used to diagnose horizontal semicircular canal BPPV . In this test, the patient lies supine, and the head is turned to each side. The presence of horizontal nystagmus , which is observed in this position, confirms the diagnosis of horizontal canal BPPV. Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV) Characterized by vertigo triggered by specific head positions, such as reaching for something overhead. Most common type of peripheral vertigo M/c Canal Affected Posterior semicircular canal > Horizontal semicircular canal > Anterior semicircular canal Etiology Head trauma (M/c cause) Vestibular neuritis Otosclerosis Meniere’s disease Otoconia Calcium carbonate crystals embedded in the macula of the utricle and saccule. Mechanism Displaced otolith from the utricle stimulates cupula of the posterior semicircular canal causing vertigo and nystagmus. Changes in head position with gravity lead to abnormal displacement of the cupula in the affected semicircular canal, stimulating vestibular afferents. This results in characteristic abnormal eye movements and vertigo. Symptoms Episodic vertigo lasting for seconds Positional vertigo: Imbalance on lying down, sitting up from a lying position, or rolling in bed or when flexing the neck. Vertigo (fatigable) may resolve temporarily but can recur after a period of rest. ± Nausea, vomiting No hearing loss No neurologic symptoms No tinnitus Diagnostic Test Dix-Hallpike Maneuver (Option B) Supine Roll Test (Option C) Procedure Image Canal tested Posterior semicircular canal (P-SCC) > Anterior semicircular canal

questions.question: A 55-year-old woman with vertigo triggered by head position changes is diagnosed with posterior semicircular canal (P-SCC) BPPV. Which of the following maneuvers is not used primarily for treating P-SCC BPPV?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Gufoni maneuver Explanation: The Gufoni maneuver is primarily used for horizontal semicircular canal BPPV , not posterior semicircular canal BPPV. Management of BPPV: Epley maneuver: (Option A) Therapeutic maneuver for repositioning of otoconial debris from the posterior semicircular canal back into the utricle. Pause at each position until nystagmus subsides or slows before moving to the next position. Post-Manoeuvre Care: Patient should remain upright for 48 hours. 8% of patients were cured by a single maneuver. If the patient remains symptomatic, the maneuver is repeated. A bone vibrator is placed on the mastoid bone to loosen the debris. Repositioning Maneuvers: Posterior Semicircular Canal BPPV Horizontal Semicircular Canal BPPV Epley’s maneuver (best) (Option A) Semont’s liberatory maneuver (Option B) Brandt-Daroff positional exercises (Option C) Forced prolonged position on the healthy side 270° Barbecue maneuver 360° Yaw rotation Liberatory maneuver Gufoni maneuver

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with acute onset of severe vertigo, nausea, and vomiting that has been persistent for the last 24 hours. He has right horizontal nystagmus that worsens with head movement. His hearing is normal, and there are no signs of weakness or dysarthria. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Vestibular neuritis Explanation: Vestibular neuritis is a peripheral vestibular disorder caused by inflammation of the vestibular nerve, often due to a viral infection. It presents with constant vertigo, nausea, vomiting, and unidirectional horizontal nystagmus that worsens with head movement. Importantly, hearing is typically unaffected , and no central neurological symptoms (e.g., weakness, dysarthria) are present. The symptoms generally peak within 24 to 48 hours and persist for several days . Vestibular Neuritis Feature Details Etiology Inflammation of the vestibular nerve, commonly due to viral infection (e.g., reactivation of HSV). Other causes include vascular and immunologic origins. Affected Structures Vestibular portion of the CN VIII, primarily affecting the superior portion of the vestibular labyrinth. Symptoms Vertigo Nausea/Vomiting Balance issues Management Antiemetics (promethazine, metoclopramide) Antihistamines (meclizine, diphenhydramine) Benzodiazepines (diazepam, lorazepam) Peripheral vs. Central Vertigo Feature Peripheral Vertigo (e.g., Vestibular Neuritis) Central Vertigo (e.g., Cerebellar Stroke) Onset of Symptoms Sudden, constant vertigo Sudden or gradual; can be constant or episodic Nystagmus Unidirectional, worsens with gaze in the direction of fast component Multidirectional or vertical, may change direction with gaze Hearing Involvement Normal (in vestibular neuritis); Ménière’s involves hearing loss No hearing involvement Neurological Signs Absent Present (e.g., dysarthria, incoordination, limb weakness) Duration of Vertigo Days to weeks Variable, may persist Head Movement Worsens symptoms Often no impact Examples Vestibular neuritis, BPPV, Ménière’s disease Cerebellar stroke, multiple sclerosis Cerebellar stroke (Option B) is a central cause of vertigo. It can present with vertigo but is typically associated with additional neurological signs like dysarthria, incoordination, visual changes, or limb weakness. Additionally, nystagmus in cerebellar stroke can change direction, unlike the unidirectional nystagmus seen in peripheral causes like vestibular neuritis. Ménière’s disease (Option C) is a peripheral vestibular disorder but is characterized by episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sense of aural fullness. Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) (Option D) is another peripheral cause of vertigo but is characterized by episodic vertigo triggered by specific head movements. It typically lasts for seconds to minutes rather than being constant, as in vestibular neuritis.

questions.question: A 12-year-old child with a history of temporal bone abnormalities presents with recurrent episodes of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, and tinnitus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Perilymph fistula Explanation: Perilymph fistula is commonly associated with temporal bone anomalies, especially in children. It typically presents with fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, vertigo, and tinnitus . In pediatric cases, congenital defects in the temporal bone can cause perilymph or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) to leak into the middle ear due to the communication between the middle ear and inner ear , especially at the Oval window and round window , which may lead to recurrent meningitis or fluid accumulation behind the tympanic membrane. Surgical exploration is often required to confirm the diagnosis and seal the fistula. Features of Perilymph Fistula Feature Description Etiology Can occur after head trauma, barotrauma (e.g., diving), temporal bone anomalies, or ear surgery (e.g., stapedectomy). Symptoms Fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, vertigo, tinnitus, and sometimes a sense of fullness in the ear. Complications Recurrent meningitis (especially in children with temporal bone defects), cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leak. Diagnosis Often clinical, based on history and symptoms; confirmed through surgical exploration if suspected. Temporal bone CT: Shows pneumolabyrinth, accumulation of fluid in the middle ear, and/or ossicular chain disruption, but also can often be normal. Treatment Surgical closure of the fistula to prevent further complications, such as meningitis; limited improvement in hearing. Prognosis Hearing improvement post-surgery is usually limited; however, vertigo symptoms often improve or resolve. Meniere’s disease (Option A) is characterized by episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness, but it is more commonly seen in adults . The child’s temporal bone abnormality and associated symptoms make perilymph fistula a more likely diagnosis. Vestibular neuritis (Option C) presents with acute, severe vertigo but does not involve hearing loss or tinnitus . It is typically caused by viral inflammation of the vestibular nerve, and there is no connection to temporal bone anomalies, making it an unlikely diagnosis here. Labyrinthitis (Option D) is associated with severe vertigo and hearing loss, usually following viral or bacterial infections. However, it is not commonly related to temporal bone anomalies or fluctuating hearing loss, as seen in perilymph fistula. Reference: Dhingra Diseases Of Ear, Nose And Throat & Head And Neck Surgery, Edition 8, Pg 54. Scott-Brown’s Otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 8th Edition, Chapter 20: Balance Disorders In Children, Pg 225 https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/perilymph-fistula#

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with intermittent vertigo, hearing his footsteps loudly and a sensation of fullness in his ear. He experiences vertigo triggered by loud noises and changes in pressure, but there is no history of recent infection or trauma. An audiogram is done, and it suggests Mixed hearing loss. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence (SSCD) Explanation: Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence (SSCD) is characterised by Mixed hearing loss (CHL) due to dehiscence (thinning or absence of bone) over the superior semicircular canal , creating a " third window " in the inner ear. Patients often report symptoms like autophony (hearing their own body sounds more loudly), pulsatile tinnitus , and vertigo triggered by loud noises ( Tullio phenomenon ) or changes in pressure ( Valsalva maneuver ). The air-bone gap in SSCD is due to a third window phenomenon caused by the dehiscence, which shunts acoustic energy away from the cochlea and enhances bone conduction, not due to pathology in the ossicles or tympanic membrane. Labyrinthitis (Option B) causes sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) . It often occurs after viral or bacterial infections of the middle ear and presents with severe vertigo, hearing loss, and sometimes tinnitus. There is no association with autophony or vertigo triggered by loud sounds or pressure changes. Ménière's disease (Option C) presents with episodic vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) , tinnitus, and aural fullness. However, it does not cause the "third window" symptoms like those seen in SSCD. The episodes of vertigo are longer and occur in attacks, often lasting minutes to hours , whereas SSCD is more positional and triggered by sound or pressure. Vestibular neuronitis (Option D) is a purely vestibular condition , causing sudden onset vertigo without any associated hearing loss or tinnitus . It is believed to be due to a viral inflammation of the vestibular nerve, and symptoms typically resolve within days to weeks without lasting auditory symptoms. Reference: Dhingra Diseases Of Ear, Nose And Throat & Head And Neck Surgery, Edition 8, Pg 52, 53, 54. Scott-Brown’s Otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 8th Edition, Chapter 65:Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence (SSCD), Pg 843
